title: Makar Sankranti
summary: Makar Sankranti, also known as Uttarāyana or Sankrānti, is a prominent Hindu observance and a mid-winter harvest festival primarily celebrated in India and Nepal. Occurring typically on January 14th (or 15th in a leap year), it signifies the sun's transition from Sagittarius to Capricorn and its northward movement. The festival is dedicated to the solar deity Surya, symbolizing a new beginning. It is observed with diverse multi-day festivities across various regions, known by different names such as Pongal, Magh Bihu, and Khichari. Celebrations include colorful decorations, melas, kite flying, bonfires, feasts, and the worship of Surya, Vishnu, and Lakshmi.
key_points: Makar Sankranti is a Hindu observance and a mid-winter harvest festival in India and Nepal.
It is celebrated annually on January 14th (or 15th on a leap year).
The festival marks the sun's transition from Sagittarius to Capricorn (makara) and its northward movement (Uttarāyana).
It is dedicated to the solar deity, Surya, symbolizing a new beginning, and involves the worship of Vishnu and Lakshmi.
Known by numerous regional names across India and beyond, such as Pongal, Magh Bihu, and Uttarayana.
Festivities include social gatherings, melas (fairs), kite flying, bonfires, and feasts.
timeline: Annually, the festival is celebrated on January 14th (or 15th in a leap year).
The occasion marks the precise transition of the sun from the zodiac of Sagittarius to Capricorn.
The celebration coincides with the sun's movement from south to north, known as Uttarāyana.
The Magha Mela, an associated fair, is mentioned in the ancient Hindu epic Mahabharata, indicating its long-standing tradition.

current_status: Makar Sankranti is currently a widely observed and culturally significant Hindu festival celebrated annually across India and Nepal. It continues to be marked by diverse regional names and unique traditions, including religious worship, social gatherings, and various festive activities.
future_prospects: As a deeply rooted cultural and religious tradition, Makar Sankranti is expected to continue its annual observance with enduring significance. Future developments will likely focus on preserving its diverse regional customs and potentially adapting some celebrations to modern contexts while maintaining its core spiritual and communal aspects. Its widespread popularity suggests ongoing intergenerational transfer of traditions.
